oai_dc:dc.dc:title: STABILITY OF LOW-CRESTED AND REEF BREAKWATERS
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: van der Meer, Jentsje W.
Pilarczyk, Krystian W.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: reef
reef breakwater
low crested breakwater
breakwater stability
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Low-crested structures are designed for some or even severe overtopping. The stability of these structures is sometimes higher than the non-overtopped structures, due to the fact that wave energy can pass over the crest, giving lower wave forces on the armour layer of the seaward slope. Low-crested structures can be classified into three categories: dynamically stable reef breakwaters, statically stable low-crested structures with the crest above swl and statically stable submerged structures. Well described investigations at various institutes (in total about 275 tests) were re-analysed and this has led to practical design formulas and graphs for each of the three classes mentioned above.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 22 (1990): Proceedings of 22nd Conference on Coastal Engineering, Delft, The Netherlands, 1990.
